citation.article-title: Rhodopseudomonas adriatica spec. nov., a new species of the Rhodospirillaceae dependent on reduced sulfur compounds.

p.s: Description of Rhodopseudomonas adriatica sp. nov.
Rhodopseudomonas adriatica (a. dri. a'ti. ca. M. L. fem. adj. pertaining to Adria, the Adriatic Sea)
Cells are Gram-negative, rod-shaped, 0.5-0.8 μm wide, 1.3 - 1.8 μm long, non-motile.
They multiply by binary fission and have the tendency to form chains of cells.
Photosynthetic membranes are of the vesicular type.
Photosynthetic pigments are bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids of the spheroidene series.
Good growth under anaerobic conditions in the light with organic carbon compounds or reduced sulfur compounds as electron donors.
Addition of Na-ascorbate stimulates growth.
Slow growth at low oxygen tension.
Sulfide and thiosulfate can be used as electron donors with CO2 as sole carbon source.
Elemental sulfur is formed during photolithotrophie growth on sulfide, and during photoheterotrophic growth with higher concentrations of sulfide or cysteine.
Growth is not possible with sulfate as sole sulfur source, or molecular hydrogen as electron
donor.
Optimum growth is at 25-30°C pH 6.5-7.0, 2.5-7.5% NaCl, and light intensities of 1000-2000 lux.
Most intermediates of the tricarboxylic acid cycle, some sugars and fatty acids, amino acids, lactate and ethanol are photoassimilated.
Not used are citrate, tartrate, benzoate, mannitol, fructose, methanol, and 2-propanol.
Nitrogen sources are ammonium salts, some amino acids, urea, and N2; not utilized are nitrate, thymine and
adenine.
Biotin and thiamine are required as growth factors.
DNA base composition of the type strain is 66.7 mol% G+C.
Source: mud and water of the marine lake Malo Jezero (Island of Mljet), Yugoslavia.
Type strain: BN 721 (6 II), deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen in Göttingen, number DSM 2781.
